question: I was seen by my optometrist on Wednesday and a neurologist on Thursday a.m. with an MRI of the brain on Thursday afternoon.  Symptons:  dark spot in lower quadurant of left eye-no vision in that area; field of vision test showed major problem with this quad.  Diagnosed as possible psedotumor celebri as optic nerve is swollen (but very minimal retinopathy).  I have had type-one diabetes for 34 years (with an average A1C of 6.0 to 6.5), white, female.  The MRI results showed "non-specific changes to the white matter" but no noticable mass.  What exactly does this mean?  A lumbar puncture has been scheduled - what does this involve and what are the reasons for doing this procedure?  Any information would be appreciated as it is Friday evening and I won't have the opportunity to discuss this with my physician until next week.
title: MRI-non-specific changes in white matter
